title.narrative: Integrated intervention to contribute to the reduction of nutrition vulnerability, mortality and morbidity of children and women in Rakhine State in Myanmar [MR4]Augmentation of in-country logistics capacity to meet the operational requirements of COVID-19 response in Myanmar [MR5];[MR6]See Annex

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters,Action C: DIPECHO

In Rakhine State, combined with poor development and lack of public infrastructures, the protracted and acute humanitarian crisis has continued to worsen since communal violence erupted in June 2012 and deteriorated dramatically in 2017. After five years of displacement, restriction of movements, limited access to basic services and livelihoods, the vulnerability to food and nutrition security remains extremely high. Access to adequate and nutritionally-balanced food remains a challenge for the most vulnerable communities, especially in rural and conflict-affected areas. To compound to an already complex situation, the protection environment and humanitarian access in Rakhine State has significantly deteriorated since 25 August 2017 following a series of armed attacks on police and military posts and subsequent security operations by the Myanmar security forces. Almost 700,000 civilians - largely stateless Muslims - have fled their homes in northern Rakhine and are now refugees in Bangladesh. The gap in essential services coverage is severe, while life-saving assistance is continuously needed as mentioned by 2018 Myanmar United Nations Humanitarian Response Plan(HRP): 599,129 people are estimated to be in need of assistance for the food security sector and 112,232 children and women should receive humanitarian support according to the nutrition sector. Limited access to Northern Rakhine is preventing humanitarian actors to gather more precise data. WFP, ICRC and FAO are among the few international organization that can address food and nutrition security needs in Northern Rakhine. The proposed project will support an integrated preventive and curative approach to contribute to the reduction of nutritional vulnerability in Rakhine state.[MR2]please see annex[/MR2] [MR3]please see annex[/MR3] [MR4] please see annex [/MR4][MR5] please see annex [/MR5]

title.narrative: Multisectoral lifesaving assistance to conflict affected IDPs and host communities in targeted districts of Taizz Governorate

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

Yemen is the worst humanitarian crisis in the world with 82% of the 27M pop. in need of humanitarian assistance and protection. This MR7 (NCE) aligns with the objectives of ECHO's 2020 Yemen HIP, by addressing both identified humanitarian needs axes (displacement due to conflict and food insecurity, health, and nutrition) by providing integrated, multi-sectoral, lifesaving support in WASH and Protection to the most vulnerable IDPs and their host communities affected by conflict to all three districts of Taizz City. All target locations are under the authority of the internationally recognized government of Yemen. CARE's extensive experience in Yemen and acceptance by local communities assures CARE's ability to successfully implement the proposed emergency response activities The WASH interventions will be part of the Acute Watery Diarrhea (AWD) and cholera response and address the communities' significant need for safe water and sanitation. The AWD & cholera response activities will address the current needs generated by the AWD crisis in the targeted areas (according to WHO, Taizz Governorate had the 3rd highest number of deaths due to cholera between Jun-Aug 2019). Through case management, CARE will ensure that the most at risk men, women, girls, and boys can access protection services. (See Annex23 Taizz Map) .CARE will remain vigilant and monitor population movements towards Taiz governorate. Recently, Authorities in the North and South asked UN & NGOs to adjust programming to respond to the CoVID-19 threat. CARE is already mainstreaming COVID prevention and awareness messages in hygiene awareness training and will design a CoVID mitigation to reduce infection rates and program current activities CoVID sensitive (Annex5.9 Sphere CoVID & Annex 31 Yemen_COVID_Weekly_Snapshot_130920).

title.narrative: Improving living conditions within IDP hosting sites in Yemen

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

In Yemen, the combination of food insecurity, lack of dignified shelter and legal documentation, no proper water and sanitation facilities, compounded by the depletion of resources of both IDPs and host communities, has led to the reduction of households (HHs) purchasing power, poor access to basic service, collapse of HH and community support network, child labor and abuse, early marriage, and substandard living conditions. These problems are further complicated by the lack of updated information available on the actors, services, and gaps at IDP hosting sites.The proposed intervention adopts a Projectized Site Management and Coordination (PSMC) approach at IDP hosting sites to simultaneously address the aforementioned issues through (a) systematic strengthening of coordination structures, combined with long-term capacity building of partners, and (b) integrated multi-sectorial service delivery at IDP hosting sites.MR02: Through CCCM and hardware interventions, the Danish Refugee Council (DRC), Norwegian Refugee Council (NRC), and ACTED will ensure that basic services are present in critical IDP hosting sites and are up to international and national standards. These services include reception services for new arrivals; shelter and WASH infrastructure; protection mainstreaming and multi-sectorial referrals; mobile protection services (DRC Al Zuhra, Hodeidah - non essential changes 20.10.20: activities moved to West Coast) as well as active coordination of interventions at targeted sites. DRC, NRC, and ACTED will support in establishment and maintenance of national and local coordination structures, ensure delivery of a harmonized training and mentorship package, and ensure the prioritized IDP Hosting Sites meet acceptable standards. IOM will join the consortium in May 2019, and they will contribute to and follow the general strategy of the consortium.

title.narrative: Integrated Health and Nutrition Support for Conflict-Affected Populations in Al Dhale’e Governorate of Yemen

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

The International Rescue Committee (IRC) proposes a 3,903,970 EUR Action from 1 April 2019 for 24 months as a continuation of the existing ECHO-funded Action in Al Dhale’e governorate, Yemen. This Action will contribute to the wider Yemen Humanitarian Response Plan (YHRP) by reaching 334,078 direct beneficiaries and contributing to the reduction in morbidity and mortality among conflict-affected populations. Since the crisis began in 2015, scarce employment opportunities have led to a loss of income and disruptions to food, fuel and medicine imports have led to a shortage of products and a sharp rise in prices. Hygiene practices and sanitation standards and systems are unsafe and millions of children are at risk of diarrhoea and acute respiratory tract infection, malnutrition and food insecurity. Civilians face serious risks to safety, well-being and basic rights, with tens of thousands killed or injured since 2015, among them at least 17,700 civilians. The IRC will address these concerns through four integrated results: R1. Communities are protected from and treated for communicable and non-communicable diseases (NCDs), including mental health conditions; and women and adolescent girls are protected from and treated for the complications of pregnancy and childbirth; R2. Children under the age of five and Pregnant-and Lactating Women (PLW) are protected from and treated for acute malnutrition; R3. Communities have access to watery diarrheal treatment centres to reduce morbidity and mortality (ending in March 2020); R4. People are safe in their communities and receive support when they experience harm.

title.narrative: Integrated Multi-Sector Interventions for Conflict-Affected Communities in Dhamar and Shabwah governorates in Yemen

description.narrative: Action A: Man made crisis and natural disasters

Relief International (RI) proposes a 23-month Action (originally submitted as RI-UK Ref No. 2018/01139) to address the Nutrition and Health needs of affected populations in Wusab Al Ali, Wusab As Safil and Dawran Aness districts of Dhamar governorate. RI will implement an integrated project, continuing to target 2 health facilities (HF) and 1 district hospital where RI is currently working through ECHO HIP 2018; RI will add 2 new health facilities in Wusab As Safil district, most affected by IDP influx. RI will also refer patients to Uthmah hospital. As of May 2020, RI will support 2 fixed HFs and additional sites in Shabwah governorate. Through this Action, RI will support a catchment population of 65,082 people. In both Dhamar and Shabwah governorates, the MoPHP and GHOs prioritized the facilities selected, and RI confirmed needs through detailed facility assessments. Clusters in both areas has asserted that Dhamar and Shabwah are underserved and ranking high on HNOs Health and Nutrition index. RI received support letters, facilitating permissions to access these areas to minimize delays in implementation. The project will also support Nutrition activities including malnutrition screening and treatment for SAM cases in Dhamar. RI will provide the HFs with equipment, staff incentives, medical supplies, operational costs and build staff capacity. With ECHO support, RI will provide hygiene and health awareness activities through Community Health Volunteers (CHVs). A dedicated emergency response component will be deployed as per the COVID context and potential cholera outbreaks.
